Choices:  A: gathering of information B: communication C: feel relaxed D: kill boredom E: social bonding<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Input<n>One morning, Jane woke up early on a Saturday morning.  She made coffee, put on a bathing suit, and went to the lake for her favorite Saturday morning exercise activity: canoeing. As she was paddling out to the lake, a flock of ducks flew overhead. The ducks were flying in a single line, each one following the line in front of it. As soon as they reached the center of the lake, the ducks dropped in a V-formation and headed straight for shore. The line on the surface of the water seemed so regular and precise, Jane thought the activity was planned.  What was the odds of the flock of ducks making it all the way to the shore without a single foul-up? Explain your  reasoning.<n><n>### Response<n>The flock of ducks was not flying in a single line.  The flock was actually flying in a V shape, and the odds of the entire flock making it all the way shore was not that far out.<n><n>### Input A person has a piece of paper, 1 foot in length.  He can fold it in half as many times as needed until it fits in a 4 inch by 4 inch cube.  How many times did they fold it?  (Note: It can't be unfolded.  You can only fold it.  You cannot cut the paper.)<n><n>### Response Not at all sure if my answer is correct here.. but I gave it a try..<n>### Response - Part 1:<n>When the person has to fold the piece of paper, in half to make two equal halfs, then he will have to fold again to make two halfs of half, then two halfs of 1half, then 2halfs of 1half and so on.<n><n>When each halfs of half fits to become a quarter, then each quarter will fit in the cube to make it a quarter of the cube size.<n><n>###Response - Part 2:<n>Folding that piece of paper in half makes the paper become 1/2 its original size and the piece of paper becomes 1/4 its initial size.<n>And so one, will keep on folding down until it fits in its initial size or the first layer of cube is created.<n><n>###

The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>### Input:Where would you see people in uniform playing with a ball? Choices:  A: active B: hunger C: in motion D: wakefulness E: lay down<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The correct response is letter "D".<n><n>The meaning of "had never seen this much":<n><n>### Instructions to write multiple-choice response for Task 2:<n><n><n>## Instructions: <n>### 1. Find the letter of the choice that best completes the request. <n><n>## Instrucions: <n><n>## Task Description: <n>### Instruction <n>Answer the following multiple choice choice.<n>##### *Multiple Choice:<n>Damon took two loaves of bread and split each loaf down the middle, then he ate two halves and gave two halves each to two of his sons. Each son ate one half of the bread that they received. For how many loaves of bread did Damon originally bake? ⋆:3<n><n>Answer A is incorrect. "Gave two halves" cannot be "2 halves". "Two loaves" implies that more than two loaves were initially given.<n><n>A.<n><n>5<n><n>```<n>2<n>```<n><n>B.<n><n>3<n><n>```<n>5<n>```<n><n>C.<n><n>8<n><n>```<n>10<n>```<n><n>D.<n><n>4<n><n>```<n>6<n>```<n><n>### Output<n>5<n>

How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>### Input:If you tell you boss your suffering from boredom they'll likely tell you to get back to what? Choices:  A: dream B: fiddle C: watch film D: see new E: work<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>---<n>#### Multiple Choice:<n><n>- [ ] A: B: C: D: E:<n><n>---<n><n><n>### **Input:** If you're in a room and it's cold, the only reasonable action is to:<n><n>- [ x ] A: Do nothing. Cold rooms are a sign of maturity.<n>- [ x ] B: Do nothing: It's the natural way to feel in a cold room.<n>- [ x   ] C: Take your clothes off, there's probably a fireplace in the room somewhere.<n>- [ x  ] D: Put on a jumper, you'll feel warmer soon.<n><n>---<n># Input: You're playing your favorite game on your smartphone and you need to restart it. However, you're out of power and need to plug your charger. What does it imply?<n>Answer: that my phone is dead<n><n>### Input : To the untrained ear, what does this melody sound like?<n><n>Input: A) The notes “eeeee”; B) A high pitch. C) A very low pitch. D) Not a “real” song<n><n>### Response : <n><n>---<n><n>- [ ]   <---   A: eeeee<n>- [ ]   B: high pitch; <n>- [   ] C: low pitch<n>- [   ] D: not a “real” song <n><n>- [ x   <> Not a “real”   song  <n><n>---<n><n>### **Instruction:**<n><n>If you can't get an adjective to fit a noun, you can always try ____.<n><n>### **Demostration:**<n><n>Input: She's a very lovely, intelligent, and ambitious young lady.<n>Answer:  She looks good on paper.<n><n>Input: He had a very intelligent friend who went to college at the age of 16.<n>Answer:  I like the odds.<n><n>Input: John was a very kind, generous, and good-looking boy.<n>Answer: Well, we already covered kindness, generosity, and appearance.<n><n>Input: My dog is a very smart, affectionate, and lovely fellow.<n>Answer: His owner loves him.<n><n>

Choices:  A: orchestra B: baritone woodwind sound C: symphony D: play music E: high school band<n><n>### Response:		<n>This can be done in either of the following two ways.<n><n>### #1-Using the IF statement<n><n>```<n><If><n>  <IfCondition><n>    <Then><n>      Orchestra<n>    </Then><n>    <Else><n>      Symphony<n>    </Else><n>  </IfCondition><n></If><n>```<n><n>### #2-Using the Case statement<n><n>```<n>Case<n><CaseCondition1><n>  <Then>Orchestra<n></CaseCondition1><n><CaseCondition2><n>  <Then>(symphony)<n></CaseCondition2><n></Case><n>```<n><n>This is a 2-line case statement, so use 3-line case statements when trying to solve each of the conditions.<n><n>### Output:<n><n>```<n><Case><n>  <CaseCondition1><n>    <Then>(orchestra)<n>  </CaseCondition1><n></Case>  <n>```<n><n>## Submission Instructions<n><n>> Submit your code via our Canvas course, and we will review your solution. Do not make code submissions here.<n><n>```<n>Code Submission Instructions:<n>  1. Go through each of the problems.<n>  2. On each problem, provide the correct solution.<n>  3. If no solution is provided, create a new blank problem.<n>  4. Submit your work on Canvas by Sunday, 5pm."

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>### Input:An expressway can suffer from traffic, this traffic gets worse the closer you get to any what? Choices:  A: michigan B: map C: american city D: rest stops E: country<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Instructions:Below are some simple words and sentences, rewrite each in a complex sentence (with the simple sentence as a dependent clause) but keep the original meaning.<n><n>#### Word:<n>Rewrite: In 2016 I went for lunch at a restaurant close to the office. My order arrived within 20 minutes.<n><n>Word:<n>Complex sentence: In 2020 while the world was battling COVID-19, I worked from home like all others. My colleagues and I met via web conferencing for work.<n><n>#### Sentence:<n>Rewrite: Last week the store near to my house was having a discount sale. I went to the store and bought two new shirts.<n><n>Sentence:<n>Complex sentence and paraphrased: Last week there was a discount sale at the store near my house. Since I was already visiting this store, I purchased two new shirts while there.<n><n>### Words:<n>The last 3 months of 2016 were very busy for me. I went to parties every weekend to celebrate Christmas and New Years.<n><n>After the parties were over, I would come home and go to bed.<n><n>The following morning I would return to my hectic schedule.<n><n>I worked in an office but I also had to go home to continue studying for my college program.<n><n>As soon as I was done studying for the evening, I would go to parties again.<n><n>After that busy time in my life, I was never the same.<n><n>### Paragraphs:<n>After the new administration came into power in 2017, I wanted to go see one of the most popular singers in our country, Adele. I knew she was performing in the city of Vancouver in British Columbia. In order to see the concert, my wife and I booked a hotel room and planned to leave the house early so we could get to Vancouver in time to get decent seats. However, it was a long drive and we had to drive on very difficult roads in order to reach the airport. Once again this summer, my wife and I were planning to take our children and grandchildren to visit me in my house in Spain where I own a vacation villa. Our main goal for this trip was to go with the children to a water park near Val
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>### Input:What can someone feeling happiness fall into? Choices:  A: lead to laughter B: love C: laughter D: smiles E: tears<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input:  A,B or D

Choices:  A: boat B: ocean C: pond D: end of line E: ocean<n><n>### Response:		F<n><n>The backyard cannot contain ocean or pond, which are located in the sea. The word end of line only pertains to the location of the fishing line.<n>End of Line is not an option, because it only applies to the fishing line. There is nothing specific it contains and also cannot contain "where" the line is coming from. It is not in the backyard, nor is it the end of the line.<n><n>### Input:"Where did they come from?" Choices A: Mars B: The moon C: Nearby stars D: The sun<n><n>### Response:"The moon"<n><n>They came from the moon as the text states.<n><n>### The answer for all multiple choice questions should be a complete, thought out reason for the answer.<n>### Please leave the multiple choice answer as a complete paragraph in your response.<n><n>### Write your response in a Microsoft Word document titled "HW2 - Your Last Name.docx."<n><n>### **Please submit your file in Google Classroom.**

She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>### Input:Two friends wanted to spend a quiet evening together, what did they go see? Choices:  A: wedding B: friend's house C: internet cafe D: movie E: restaurant<n><n>### Response:		If you wanted to have a quiet evening together with your closest friends, who would think about having a wedding with them? Or maybe you would think of spending money to watch a movie. Also, you could have a quiet evening at someone's house. This would be the best choice for those who just want to communicate with very close friends without a big party. Finally, you could have an evening out of a café. But I think that it is good to have an evening at home with your closest relatives. Maybe you can discuss new plans about future.<n>### Answer:<n>Answer: The answers are A, B, C, D, and E.<n>### Instruction and Demo: What is the average value of the data set?<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input: The average of a five digit number is divisible 4. The second digit is bigger than the first, the third bigger than the second, the fourth bigger than the third, and the fifth bigger than the fourth. What is the average of the five-digit number?<n>Answer: 20788<n><n>Input: For a given number, replace the numbers with their position in order and add them all up. E.g. 5927194 becomes 4972519, and then 5027499, 5013360, 5000777, and finally 5000000. The highest value of this sequence will be two orders of magnitude below the maximum value of the original sequence. Given the numbers 62277178574186468435802076767009872, we can obtain the answer to this puzzle by repeatedly converting it to 4972 and addition, 5027, 5014, 5001, and finally 5, until we obtain the value. What is the answer?<n>Answer: 179686221529076391099538696917818641<n><n>Output: The first half of the number is three times as large as the second half and the fifth digit is three times as large the fourth digit. The total number of digits is eleven. What is

The next day a man takes out 179 peanuts.  A day later he takes another 95.  And another 58.  And so on.  How many more peanuts does he take out?<n><n>### Response, part 2,example,<n>If you continue taking out from the box at the same rate as before (179 per day), you would run out of peanuts in 6 days, and the total you'd take out would be 179 * 6 = 1074.<n><n>### Requirements:<n> 1. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>### Input:The judge did not take this part of the job lightly, the man was guilty but it was his passing sentence that condemned the man to what? Choices:  A: go to jail B: incarceration C: intercourse D: death E: judgement<n><n>### Response:		the judge took the part of the job light which the man was to  be condemenned with death.<n><n><n>### Input : The manager was forced to make a costly mistake  to correct a more costly one earlier made by another employee, but that only added  to what cost? Choices: 	 A: the company’s overall productivity B: the staff members’ productivity C: the shareholders profit D: the company’s  income.<n><n>### Response : The manager made a mistake to correct another mistake at cost of the company's income.<n><n>## Solution<n>```python3<n>input = input("Enter your Instrucion")<n><n>##input = "Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>## Demonstration: Question input"<n>input1 = ''<n>result = ''<n><n>## Instruction:<n>while "?" in input:<n>	input1 = input.split("?")<n>	result = result + input1[1]<n>	<n>## Demonstrastion :<n>while "?" in result:<n>	result2 = result.split("?")[0]<n>	result+=' '<n>input = input.split(":")<n>## while condition<n>## print("Please check this answer below")<n>## print("How does this answer look like to you?")<n>## print(result)<n>## if input == result.split(":")[1]:<n>## 	print("Yes, that is correct")<n>## 	exit(0)<n>## if input!= result.split(":",1)[1]:<n>## <n>## 	print(input1)<n>## 	print('You have entered an incorrect answer')<n>## 	exit()<n>## input = input.split("How much did his purchases")<n>## if "was" in input:<n>## input2 = input.split("was")<n>## <n>## print("Answer: ", input2[1])<n>## input = input2[1].split(" ")<n>## if "kilograms" in input:<n>####  print("Answer: {0}".format(int(input[2])))<n><n>```

How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>### Input:While laid up in the hospital she tried remembering good times, like that massage on vacation that brought great what? Choices:  A: dream B: knowing C: depression D: pleasure E: nostalgia<n><n>### Response:		Knowing<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Adults and infants alike prefer the familiar over uncertainty [Evans and Loftus, 1993] and will select even negative or painful stimuli over one that is unknown. One example used in the study is that of a woman who had a car accident in her boyfriend's car. She remembers the crash even though she can't completely pinpoint it, whereas it happened many years ago, when she was five, and she doesn't recall that. She does, however, have a clear memory of the aftermath.<n>* Note: These questions are provided via open source code on [GitHub](https://github.com/hughdb/practicing.ml/tree/master/instructions-input).<n>

Choices:  A: toy store B: bar C: casino D: table E: family room<n><n>### Response:		If the students answer A or E, the response is A "Playground." Otherwise, the response is B "Class"<n><n>### Instructions: Input: Choose a letter from A-I.<n><n>### Response 1: If the students answer I, the response is I "Yes!"<n><n>### Else, If the student answer anything other than I, the response is J "No." <n><n>### Instuctions: Input: There are 5 different flavors of water: grapefruit, honeydew, cherry, blueberry and white grape. There are 5 different brands of water: SmartWater, Polar, WaterSpring, OWYN and Waterlogic. The first two columns show the amount of each flavor sold for each brand. How many cups were sold of each brand?<n><n>### Response to 1st column: If the students choose Smartwater or Polar, the response if "17 cups of water."<n>If the student chooses WaterSpring or Waterlogic, the response is "None."<n><n>### Responses to 2nd column: If the students pick grapefruit or blueberry, the response is "Mixed Flavors"<n>If the student picks honeydew, white grape or cherry, the response is "Blue 4"<n><n>### Input 1: Choose an apple. Choices: A: McIntosh B: Sweet Tart C: Fuji D: Granny Smith E: Delicious F: Gala G: Idared H: Snow Sweet I: Honeycrisp J: McIntyre K: Arkansas Black L: McDonnell M: Gravenstein N: Rome Beauty O: Red Ace P: Baldwin<n><n>### Response If the students answer A, P, I, L, E, H, M or O the response is "Not an apple"<n><n>### Otherwise, the response is "Apple: Not an apple."<n><n>### Inputs 2,3: Choose an instrument. Choices: A. Guitar B. Trumpet C. Tuba D. Harp E. Drum F. Keyboard G. Voice H. Piccolo<n><n>### For Input 2: If the student answers C, D, G, H

Choices:  A: indigestion B: died C: illness D: feel better E: throwing up<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Instructions:<n>The above examples are from a larger corpus of example responses for a certain task.  Create 2 more example responses with each one providing a correct response for every example input and question.<n><n>## Important Questions<n>I. The task is about calculating a total number of widgets shipped in each box that got shipped. The task input includes the dimensions (in inches) for a shipping box and boxes are 20 in height, 20 in length, and 20 in width. There is also a carton, which is 4 inches wide, it is 4 inches long, it is 5 inches tall, and it can hold 3 widgets. Each product is shipped in a carton and then, the cartons are shipped in each shipped box. The task instruction follows the steps below:<n><n>1. Step 1: First, calculate the product of 4, 4, and 5, which is: 4 × 4 × 5 = 80.<n>2. Step 2: The second step is to multiply each side of the rectangle by the dimensions of the carton (3 widgets x 4 inches), which is 3 × 4 = 12.<n>3. Step 3: Lastly, combine the 2nd and 3rd steps, which is: 80 × 12 = 960 widgets.<n><n>The task instruction is correct.  There are 2 inputs; 2 cartons fit inside a box and it takes 3 cartons to ship a product.<n><n>II. What was felt by the poor chicken after eating a dinner of chicken that was uncooked?   Choices: A: illness B: died C: indigestion D: felt better E: throwing up <n><n><n>#### What was felt by the chicken after eating uncooked chicken that the poor sick man ordered?<n>Choices: A: Feeling better<n><n>Answer: D is the correct answer because he got poor and sick after eating the raw chicken that he ordered.  The chicken was raw so he will feel sick and become poor.

Choices:  A: expect to die B: believe in god C: stay in D: watch movies E: eat corn<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: Expect to die<n><n>It could be death, but it also could be that someone dies. For example, you can be expect to die, but someone else dies.<n><n>### Answer: None of these answer choices is true.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Lets say I'm trying to find the sum of 100 through 125. The answer is:<n>100, 101, 102..125 = 1255.<n><n>If I were to ask to multiply any two of those values, a good answer would be:<n>(100*1) + (101*101) +... + (125*10000)<n><n>If you didn't get those values before, the output would be:<n><n>[(100*1)] + (101*(100)) +... + (125*(125)) = 1250022500 = 2768922500<n><n>And in fact, if you multiply any set of (X*Y) values where Y is more than 10 and X is less than 100, you will get the same answer.<n><n>### Response<n><n>Input: multiply any two of the values<n><n><n>This will be true.<n><n>## Input:How many squares of different sizes can you make out of a 12x12 inch piece of wood?<n><n>## Response:<n><n>Input: You can get 6 squares out of a 1-12 inch piece.<n><n>This is a valid answer.<n><n>## Input<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the question True or False.<n>### Demonstraion:<n><n>### Input1: "If you have a 5-inch square of wood, you can cut two equilateral triangles out of the board."<n>### Response: "True"<n><n>If you have a 4 inch square, then you can't cut out any equilateral triange.<n><n>### Next Question<n>### Input:<n>"True if you have a 5 inch square piece of wood, False if you have a 8-inch square piece."<n><n>### Response?<n>I don't

Choices:  A: jail B: internet cafe C: blacksmith's shop D: building E: bar<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>1.  In B<n>2.  Stella and Twinkles filled the truck in 6 hours, and with 6 workers working at the same rate as them they finished filling in 3 hours, therefore the number of hours it took to fill the truck without the extra workers was 4 hours.<n>3.  The widgets in each box are 3<n>4.  The number of widgets is 300<n>5.  Doris ships 300 widgets in each box<n>6.  B<n>

How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>### Input:Why would you not want to be working with wood? Choices:  A: blisters B: frustration C: being paid D: make money E: money<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: E (Money)<n><n>### Explanation:<n>A (Blisters) - I do not want to have blisters.<n>B (Frustration) - I also do not want to be frustrated.<n>C (Being paid) - I do not mind making money.<n>D (Make money) - I am also concerned to make money.<n>E (Money) - I want to make money.<n><n>### Input<n>We want every number input to be converted to the correct number according to instructions in the paragraph:<n><n>I want to make a cake, so I need 5/8 cups of flour. I also want to make 5/6 cup of batter. I also need 1/2 cup of milk for the batter. I also need the same amount of milk for 5/6 cup to put in the cake. Finally, I need 2 tablespoons of sugar for the batter.<n><n>### Response<n>Convert 1/2 cup for the batter to 1/4 cup and convert 1/2 cup to be put into the cake to 1/4<n><n>### Examples:<n>1/2 cup of flour<n><n>-Convert 1/2 to 1/4 - 1/4 of 1/2 = 1/8(4/8 = 1/2)<n><n>1/2 cup batter<n><n>-Convert 2/6 to 1/4 = 1/3 of 1/2<n><n>1/2 cups milk<n><n>-Convert 5/6 to 1.1428571 to get the 1/2.<n><n>### Exponentions: Example: 2^2 = 4<n><n>### Input :<n><n>This is an example of an input. It can be used to train the computer or the student about the questions that has to be answered.<n><n>### Answer :<n><n>This is the answer after the training. I use the number 6, which is 2^3.<n><n>### Question :<n><n>This is a question to the student about what is the answer to the question<n><n>### Answer: <n><n>This is the correct answer for this question about the question and the answer for the given input.<n>

Choices:  A: cash register B: desk drawer C: pay envelope D: throw away E: box<n><n>### Response:		The clerk puts them in the cash register if they put cash inside the check and deposit it into the bank when customer deposits it<n>The clerk puts them into a pay envelope if they don't write cash inside the check to be deposited into the bank<n>If the check is not written in a deposit slip, the clerk puts them in a desk drawer to be reviewed later<n>In the box if they intend to use the check as an IOU or debit to a bank account<n>The clerk throws away check when the client is asking for the cash inside on the check<n>

Choices:  A: contagious B: wrong C: last forever D: painful E: blind<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>The more you give, the more you have in return.<n><n>### Input<n>How many different 3-letter words can be made with the letters in the word PRESENT? Choices:<n>A: 4  B: 56 C: 151 D: 320 E: 1024<n><n>### Response<n>E<n><n>There are 52 + 1 ways to arrange the 3 letters in any order, so the total is:<n><n>10! C(10,3) = 3024<n><n>The 10! is there to say to not ignore possible arrangements for only a subset of the letters. (10! = 10 multiplied by the 10 - 7 terms before taking the 4th and 8th term to make 3 letters.)<n><n>### InputA farmer's field is 150m long and 50m wide. He wants to grow an equally sized crop of wheat on either side of the field, but he only has enough seeds to half the field. How long does it take to complete the project if they start planting immediately?<n>A: 5 d B: 8 d C: 17 d D: 32 d E: 121 d<n>Answer: 32<n><n>### InputOne day, Mary’s uncle gave her some money and told her to buy some new socks. After making her way to the market, she realized that there were different sock sizes (S, M, L, XL, and XXL). With only $5, Mary had to buy 3 pairs of socks. Each sock had a different cost. How many combinations of different socks and prices can Mary purchase?<n>A: 6 B: 8 C: 13 D: 24 E: 42<n>Answer: 42<n><n>### ResponseD<n><n>How many combinations there are of 3 pairs of sock and price:<n><n>3 choose 3 - 3 choose 2 - 3 choose 1<n><n>In terms of the combinations, each sock can only be with one size and one of the 3 prices. <n><n>###

There are some restrictions on how to answer this question.  For each question,  you must write a response that correctly identifies the answer.  Some questions will ask to respond multiple choice, while other questions will allow a full essay response.<n>2. If the question asks for a response in which you can enter more than one choice, be careful of including an extra choice that is technically correct (but which would not be a choice you can make in real life).  For example, if I ask you what time you started a job,  you could start your answer by saying "It was at 12:00 at midday,  at 11:59 at midnight,  at 23:59 last night, or at 00:00",<n>you cannot answer this.  You must answer either 12:01, 11:53, 00:01, 00:59, or 1:00.  (If you write that at 23:31 last night, at 00:28,  at 2:20 this morning, or at 1:25 this morning you would earn

For each case, the input should be exactly as given in the case and in the order.<n>### Demonstraion:<n>```<n>Input: What would you normally expect a mouse to say?<n>Answer: meow<n><n>Input: What would be a good thing to say?<n>Answer:"see king"<n>```<n>### Demonstaction<n>```python<n>def fun(s):<n>    return s.title()<n>```<n>### Input:Write a method named saySomething that takes in three string parameters, a name, what they want to say, and something to say in return. When your code is done, you should call the method.<n>### Demostration<n>```python<n>a=str(input("Type your Name:"))<n>b=str(input("type what would be a good thing for him to say:"))<n>c=str(input("The name of the cat is:"))   <n>saySomething(name,b,c)<n>```<n>### Answer:<n><n>### Input:"Hello my name is Adam, and I went to school today!"<n>### Response: "Meow." <n><n>### Input"what would a duck say hello?<n>### Response: Meow<n><n>### Input "Why do you always meow and say hey when you see someone?"<n>### Response: Good morning<n><n>### Insturctions:<n>### What would a puppy normally say? <n>### Choices: <n>### A: What should the puppy say?  B: meow meow<n>### C: what would a puppy normally speak?  D: woofy<n>### E: mew mew<n><n>### Response(using your knowledge of animal sounds to answer):<n><n>### Demostrating:<n>```python<n>def  sayPuppy(s):<n>    print("meow meow")<n><n>def  sayDog(s):<n>    x = 'woof'<n>    print(x)<n><n>s='What do you do when you see a puppy?'<n>sayPuppy(s)<n>sayDog(s)<n>```<n><n>### Input <n>### A. Type a string like "good morning"

Choices:  A: india B: hole C: cage D: habitat E: rain forest<n><n>### Response:		<n>##<n><n>### Input<n>Input: The number 322 is the only whole number whose digits have sums<n>that alternate between even and odd.  What is the sum of those digits?<n><n>### Response<n>##<n>Solution: 104. 3 + 2 = 5, 2 + 7 = 9, 5 + 9 = 14, 14 + 4 = 18<n><n>### Input and output:<n>Input: 148 196 365<n><n>### Response and input:<n>Input: 400<n><n>## Solution and explanation:<n>##<n>### Input<n><n>```<n><n>148 175 263<n><n>```<n><n>### Response <n><n>```<n><n>539<n><n>```<n><n>#### Input 148 and output 539:<n><n>#### Input 539 and output 148:<n><n>Input: 175 and 539 will be equivalent.<n><n>#### Input 263 and output 196<n><n>### Explaining the output:<n><n>### Explanation <n><n>#### Input 365 and output 400:<n>Input: 365 and 400 are equivalent because it is a multiple of 7 (10 and 40 are multiples of 7).<n><n>### Exercises:<n>#### Instruction and input:<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>### Solution 1:<n>### Solution 2:<n>### Solution n:<n><n>### Input 148: <n>### Input 263: <n>### All Outputs: <n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question and respond with a number.<n>### Demonstartion:<n><n>### Insturction and Input<n><n>### Response to questions<n><n>### Answer and Explanation<n><n>### Exercise<n>#### Instruction: How many answers are needed to be put into the box?<n>#### Input:<n><n>### Solutions 1:<n>## # 1<n>#### Input 1 and Response 1:<n>## Solution: 1<n>## Solution 2:<n><n>## Solution 3:<n><n>##

A new line character ('\n') needs to be used to indicate the newline.<n><n>In a 3-column format, indicate the prompt, response, and correct answer.  See example.<n><n>### Examples:<n>**Prompt:** If people are vegetarian, do they most often (a) gain wealth (b) eat plants (c) gain wealth (d) believe in god (e) sun themselves<n><n>**Response:** (c) eat plants.  The answer is given for (a) gain wealth.<n><n>**Prompt:***How long (a) does it take (b) takes (c) it takes (d) taking (e) take to make an omelet??<n><n>**Response:*** (b) takes.  The answer is listed as (c) it takes.<n><n><n>***<n><n>### Output Expectation:<n><n>Output should be the correct answer for each question.<n><n>***<n><n>**Instructions:** Write a Python program to follow the instructions below.  A new line can be written by using a '\n' character at the end.<n><n>**Examples**<n>Prompt: If people are vegetarian do they most often (A) gain wealth (B) eat plants (C) gain wealth (D) believe in god (E) sun themselves<n><n>Response: (C) eat plants. The answer is given for option (A) gain wealth.<n>Prompt: How long (A) does it take (B) takes (C) it takes (D) taking (E) take to make an Omelet<n><n>Response: (B) takes. The answer is given in option (C) it takes.<n>

The input that the program receives must match that which is stated in the instructions (including the question text).<n><n>### Demotseion:<n>In the first part of the statement, a student is asked which of the following diseases caused the rash on their arm. There are 2, 3, 4, 5, or sometimes 6 options (C, D, E, are optional). The student is allowed to choose any one of the option they see and answer the rest of the question.<n><n>## Output:<n>The computer should ask the question “what was wrong?” the student should input a letter representing the answer of what they choose from the first part of the question (e.g. letter, a, b, c, d, if they chose A, if they chose b, etc.). The computer should then reword the question and ask for an answer of what they choose. Continue to reword and ask for answers until the student inputs the correct answer (e.g. ask for b again if they enter to “c”). Note that the computer should always ask for the letter after stating the option.<n>

Choices:  A: shelf B: cellar C: refrigerator D: cupboard E: grocery store<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Explanation:<n>C. The refrigerator is where food is stored in a fridge and a canned food drive is something to do with cans (the sort of foods to put in one) and we get canned foods in a'refrigerator' (where it is cooler). B. The cellar is where we used to do our canning and we used to store food in there. A. The shelf is where we put things we can't put in the kitchen (as it is not big enough, and it isn't a cupboard, and it isn's the refrigerator as we don't get canned food in there). F. The fridge is where we keep food which is cooked and is a cool temperature, a'shelf' is made up out of stuff called'shelving units' which are things you put on a wall and put stuff in to save you using cupboard space. E. The grocery store is a place we go to get food (but it is not in a grocery store!). D. Cupboard is a place to store stuff which has its own 'place' or'space'. A 'cellar' is a place to store wine and it is in a cupboard. A fridge is in a cupboard but is not a cupboard (no more than we can just live in the refrigerator). A'shelf' is like a cupboard in a cupboard. E. The 'grocery store' is the store name.<n><n>### Output:<n>"The answer is that it is a 'b'. The cellar is a place where 'fruits' go, and canned food is a kind of fruit."<n><n><n>### Input : There is an ant problem.  If the problem is solved, the ants will completely be eradicated by using chemicals.  The ants are in 200 places inside 30 buildings.  If we don't fix them, it will be worse next year.  How many chemicals must we use to solve the problem?<n><n>### Demonnstration:<n>Input of 200, and the first answer is 200.  Input is 30 and the first answer is also 30.  Input is one and the first answer is one.<n>

Choices:  A: amusement B: losing money C: charmed D: having fun E: win money<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>```java<n>public static String charmed(String[][] input) {<n>    int oneCount = 0;<n>    int twoCount = 0;	// number of "a pairs" that are a pair on their own<n>    int twoCount2 = 0;			// total number of pairs<n>    int[][] count = new int[14][90];//counts all number combinations<n>    boolean[][] inArray = new boolean[14][91];//checks if numbers are in the carton box<n><n>    for (String[] string : input) {<n>        for (int j = 0; j < string[0].length(); j++) {<n>            if (j == 0) {<n>                count[j][0] = 1;<n>            } else if (j == 1) {<n>                count [j][2] = 1; //counts the number of "a pairs."<n>                oneCount++;<n>            } else if(j > 1 && j < 30){//checks for two pairs and the box is not full.<n>                oneCount--;<n>                if (inArray[j-1] == false) { //if the number isn't in the box already<n>                    twoCount2++;<n>                    inArray[j-1]=true;<n>                    twoCount++; //this is a two pair as well<n>                    count[j-1][twoCount-1] =2;<n>                }<n>            }<n>            else {<n>                if(j>30 && j < 90 && inArray[j-31] == false){<n>                    twoCount--;<n>                    if (inArray[90-1] == false ) {<n>                        count[90-1][90] = 16;<n>                        twoCount2++;<n><n><n>                        inArray[90-2] = true;<n>                        twoPair = true;<n>                    }<n>                }<n>                else {<n>                    System.out.println("invalid input");<n>                    break;<n>                }<n><n>            }<n>        }<n>    }<n><n>        return "The family was playing cards with " + twoCount2 +" two pair, " + oneCount + " one pair, and " + count[90

What is the probability that your schedule will call for feeding a different resident on every day you have to care for?<n><n>### Solution<n><n>27  = 33<n><n>33 / 27 = 33 / 9<n><n>33 /9 * 12 = 13<n><n>### Instructions : What is the total number of different 4-legged animals?<n><n>### Cats<n><n>### Solution :<n><n>15<n><n>### Input <n><n>### The bookstore has sold some books.<n>### The total number of books sold was over 3200 and less than 5300. <n>### If the total number of books sold in that time was 4300, <n>### how many books were sold for the time?<n><n>### Answer<n><n>4.0<n><n>### Instructioin : What is the lowest number of times that one set of weights can be stacked in 5 minutes without <n>### leaving a piece of equipment empty?<n><n>### Weights<n><n>### 20lbs<n><n>### 30lbs<n><n>#20 - 30 = 10<n><n>### Solution: How long will 41 gallons of gas last if the cost is $3.

Input:Where would there a connection to connect to another place?<n>> <n>> <n>> Q02. Input:What would happen If all the batteries are drained.<n>> <n>> Method: BATTERY(self):<n>> 	Return battery drained<n><n>### Input01:<n>```python<n>class Connection:<n>    def __init__(self,input,output):<n>        self.input=input # Connected to some place<n>    }<n>            <n>Connection.BATTERY(self)<n>```<n><n>### Output01:<n>```pyton<n>>>> connection1= Connection('wires,electrical circuited', 'wires, electrical circuit cnnected')<n>***connection1 is now a connection that is connected to somewhere and somewhere else.***<n>>>> connection1.BATTERY<n>>>> Connection.BATTERY = 180ms of charge from the batteries<n>```<n><n>## Task02:<n>Implement the methods in the `Wires` class shown below and <n><n>##

You can think of a way that you would answer this question and what you expect the other person would do for it to make sense. You could think of the steps that you would take when you have a question about where you might see something. There are multiple possible answers that you could give and it depends on how specifically the question is asked. Be specific! I should be answered in the form of a complete sentence. You can't expect to simply provide a string of letters and words. You will then need to provide an answer to the next question. This question may seem simple, but it is possible to answer incorrectly. When something is moving, you can usually see it if you're looking at it. In the case of football games, it's easy to see people running around, trying to catch the ball. However, the ball is moving around and so it's difficult to see it. This question asks where you would expect to see people. Your task should answer that question based on what you see. In this case, I think you would expect to see them looking at the field or the airplane, or even the ceiling.<n><n>### Input 3:<n>3. Enter one or two complete sentences that describe how you would expect to answer that question, what others might respond to, and how you're answering the question correctly.<n>Answer: If the question were "Where would people be looking for some things which can move but are not currently moving?" then I would respond to the question: A: Where would people expect to see people looking at some things that could potentially move around soon? Where would you expect to see someone trying to catch a ball in a football game? A: Where would people be looking to see if a ball were going to fall from a balloon? In the case of a football game, I think you would see people looking at the field or at another part of the stadium. I could also be watching a boxing match where you expect to see people trying to catch the ball as it bounces around.

The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>### Input:Deciding to watch tv or play with your cell phone might be a routine but they provide no help in being able to do what? How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>### Input:If you're standing in line and the line isn't moving what might you feel? Choices:  A: order B: queueing up C: wait turn D: fatigue E: anger<n><n>### Response:		If you're standing in a long line but the line isn't progressing it usually creates either A: fatigue or B: frustration. Sometimes it isn't clear whether your line is moving until you get to the front. Sometimes waiting times aren't posted, so you might feel like B. A lot of people hate standing in lines but it's more often than not a part of everyday life.<n><n>### Comment:<n>In this task, there are a couple of different kinds of instruction. The first kind of instruction gives a scenario and asks a question, so you are asked to write a short essay to answer that question. The second kind of instruction gives an incomplete sentence and asks you to complete it with a single word or brief phrase. In some cases, it may seem more appropriate for writing an essay about a question. But in many other cases, it is appropriate for writing just a single word or phrase.<n><n>### How to choose if it is advisable respond by short written statement or an essay?<n><n>#### Short response<n><n> <n>To choose whether it is advisable respond to a question by a short statement or an essay, you must first decide whether we are asked a multiple choice question: <n> * if we have a multiple choice question, then we can answer by a short statement because the choice is predefined and it has to be single statement, or answer by an essay <n> <n>To the question below, would you respond by a short statement <n><n>* if you decide yes, then the answer is the complete sentence with all the details;<n>* if you decide no, then you must respond by an essay because it is not a multiple choice question.<n>

Is my sister(s)s(s\#2) older than me?<n><n>### Solution <n><n>Say s is the answer. <n>if s==0 then s is not a nublar number<n><n>### Explanation:<n>If one of the sisters is 12, we have a solution, and an answer.<n>   1. 21 >= 12<n>   2. false<n>    <n>If both sisters are 12, we will have an answer and a solution, but the question is unsolvable. <n>   1. s+1<n>   2. false (because s+1 will be 13)<n><n>### Input<n><n>> What is the value of 1/6, 2/6, 3/6<n><n>### Solution<n><n>There are two ways to show that 1/6 is equal to 1/2, 1/2 is equal to ½, and 2/6 is equal to one third.  <n><n>#### (1)<n><n>We know (1/x=anything)/(1)=0<n>Also 2/x=anything/2=anything/2<n><n>When we plug the value of 1 for 1/x, we have 1/2=anything/(anything)<n><n>And when we plug the value of one for the numerator(2/x), x=anything, so we have x/anything=2/anything<n><n>So<n><n>(x/anything)=1/anything<n><n>And (2/anything/x)=2/anything<n>and<n>(a)=x<n>so we get (anything)/x=1/x<n><n>When x=1, we get 1/1=1<n><n>And when x=3, we get 3/1=3<n><n><n><n>#### (2)<n><n>We know if x=2, then x!=1<n>Therefore 22=2<n>So  (2/x):((1/0)=2<n>And therefor 22:2=1<n><n>(1/0

In this case, it should be the function to test.<n><n>`def test_function1(arg1,arg2,arg3)`<n><n>    print "Hello1"<n><n>`def test12(arg1,arg3)`<n>    print "arg1"<n><n>`test34()<n><n>### Input /Output<n>It is the same as above.<n><n>### Comment<n>The only code block that needs to change is the test code block in the last section. Change this code block to match the above test code block. You need only add arguments to your existing function.<n><n>### Output<n>This is the output to print to the console, when called. Remember, the function should still pass its tests.<n><n>### Example Answer<n>You may use the function defined in the previous section to write your code.<n><n>### Solution<n><n><n>### InputOutput<n><n>### Comment/Explanation<n>Think about all the possible values of the integer arguments.<n><n>### Answer<n><n>### Output 4 pints for each pint of coffee<n><n>### Answer - Movement<n><n>### Output Answer<n><n><n>### Solution (Output)<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>### Input:What would a person do if he or she just woke up? Choices:  A: drink tea B: thank god C: open eyes D: feel angry E: complete sentence<n><n>### Response:		<n>1. C<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the question in your own words.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: How much should you study? Choices:  I need to study all day  I can study until I fall.  I should study a hour before bed every day  I can study 3 hours a day every day<n><n>Output: You should study one hour a day<n><n>Example:<n><n>### Input : How should you react? Choices:  It is better to have friends than relatives  It is better to be loved by all your friends  Your family will leave you a day  Better to have a small family.  You will always have a place in family<n><n>Output : "What you do is not important, what is important is who you do it with  "<n><n>### Input   :How does an expert feel about learning something new? Choices:  He wants new learning  He wants to study  He does not want to learn from childish people  He wants to be more skillful

If the period of time had been 201 days, what would have been the expected value?<n><n><n>## Solution :<n>Solution for 1:<n>```{<n>1: print "Answer:", 2<n>2: <n>if ((a == 1) or (a == 2))<n>    print ("2")<n>else <n>    print ("1")<n>} <n>```<n><n>Solution for 2:<n>```python<n>import time<n>inputs = ["Coffee table", "Bed", "coffee mug", "dog bed"]<n>choices = ['Bed', 'Coffee table', 'Coffee mug', 'dog bed']<n><n>def my_func(index, my_list):<n>    return index, my_list<n><n>while True:<n>    index, my_list, my_func = input().split()<n>    if index == "break":<n>        break<n>    print("This is my_list:", my_list)<n>    print("My function returns:", my_func(index))<n>    print("Index:", index)<n>```<n>![solution1](https

How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>### Input:If you're known to buy presents for others often you would be called what? What was the quantity of candies delivered on 22nd?<n><n>### Response<n>>There are 33 extra candies on 22nd. 33 * 2 / 22 ≈ 3.57.<n><n>### Input><n>When a train passes through a station it has to wait for 3 minutes. What will the travel time be if the train travels at 1000 kph?<n><n>### response><n>1000 * 3 ≈ 3000. 3000 / 60 = \>50.<n><n>### input><n>If 372 is subtracted from a two-digit number, the result is 11 less than three times that number. How many are in the resulting number, if that number is 22?<n><n>### answer<n>22 = 2, 2 is 11 less, 3 times 22 is 66, 66 - 372 = 296 - 371 = 22 732 - \> 725 <n>

Choices:  A: down a river B: city C: repair shop D: parking lot E: neighbor's house<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Solution<n>First, define a string that will hold our instruction in it's parts, and define an int variable that will hold our answer with a default set at -1 and a bool that will set true if we passed the multiple choice question and not false.<n><n>```<n>    //string to hold the instruction<n>    string instruction;<n>    //String to hold the answer<n>    string answer;<n>    //boolean for passing multiple choice question.<n>    bool passedMCQ = false;<n>    ```<n><n>```<n>    while (cin>>instruction){<n>        //Check if the instruction to check with mcq.<n>        if(instruction == "Answer the following multiple choice questions." &&!passedMCQ){<n>            //Reset the boolean.<n>            passedMCQ = false<n>            //Start a for in<n>            for(int c=0;c<instruction.size();c++){<n>                    //String to hold answers.<n>                    string option;<n>                    //String for multiple choice question.<n>                    string mcq;<n>                    //Multiple choice question string we will check.<n>                    string multipleChoice;<n>                    //boolean for checking multiple choice.<n>                    bool matched = false;<n>                cout<<'Enter the multiple choice question to check: '<<endl;<n>                cin>>multipleChoice;<n>                //Check if multiple choice is equal to the mcq we have.<n>                for(int k=0;k<multipleChoice.size();k++){<n>                        if(multipleChoice[k] == instruction[c]){<n>                                matched = true;<n>                                mcq = multipleChoice;<n>                                break;<n>                        }<n>                }<n>                //If matched is true.<n>                if(matched){<n>                        //Change the boolean to true<n>                        matched = true;<n>                }<n>                option = multipleChoice;<n>                //Output what we get in the mcq.<n>                cout<<"What is "<<mcq<<"? ";<n>                //Enter the answer in a string.<n>                cin>>answer;<n>                if(answer == option){<n>                        //Pass the MCQ<n>                        passedMCQ = true;<n>                        //Reset the mcq string.<n>                        mcq = "";<n>                        //Get output

How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>### Input:She had been applying for job for weeks with no call back, she knew she was qualified, so what did she feel? Choices:  A: employment B: frustration C: stress D: working hard E: love<n><n>### Response:		She felt love for her family, friends, the man she met at 24 and who she married at 28. she felt the weight was not on her shoulder anymore.

You should use the letter r when writing the name of your variable. You will need to define the value of the variable before you can use it. Just leave out radius and input the number and you will get an error.<n>Remember to print your answer to the screen as a whole number. The number format should be in scientific notation (e.g. 2.5e3).<n><n><n>### Demonic Example:<n>Input: radius = 4<n><n>Output: area = 16.000E-002<n><n>### Demony example:Instructions:<n>Input:radius = 3<n><n>Output:perimeter = 16.448E-001<n><n>

Choices:  A: pond B: underwater C: aquarium D: lake superior E: body of water<n><n>### Response:		A<n>#### Justifications:<n>* One way to ice fish is by simply walking out on the ice or by building a large ice structure. The structure is referred to as an ice shanty.[Ice shanty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ice_shanty)<n>A shanty is a structure built especially to facilitate ice fishing. The fishing shelters protect the fisherman from wind and weather, and provide dry storage for ice fishing equipment and a warm, weather-proof area to build a fire.[Shanty](https://www.google.com/search?q=shanty&safe=active&rlz=1C2AVSA_enUS762US762&sxsrf=AOaemvJ0uSy5VG02rF6D3-3B0UmG9-C28Q:1612912811101&source=lnms&tbm=isch&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwj8-8Dz3_3wAhV7Z8AKHe5zCKAQ_AUoAXoECAQQAQ&biw=1366&bih=664&dpr=1.9)<n><n>

They get a $100 refund<n>- It is 4/5 as expensive as the new model is.  Cost: $400<n>- It is 50% more expensive than the new model is<n>- The other one is $100 cheaper<n>- Its cost is 1/10 of the cost of the new model<n><n>### Response<n><n>The correct response is C which is the one that has the largest price and the one with the biggest price difference.<n><n>### Other<n><n>- You can't use spaces<n>- A word can only appear once<n>- Each line is one word<n><n>### Input and Output<n><n>Input: John got 36 hours of community service because he was running late to a school party. His friend Dan got 22 days of community service for lying to his mother. How many days of community service did John have to get because he was running late. Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Adam and Sam ran out of food.  There were 6 apples and 3 oranges. They got 7 pears and 2 bananas.  How many pears and bananas did they get together? Answer: 13<n><n>Input: It costs $10 to watch a movie at the theater.  On Monday, he bought one ticket to the movie theater.  On Tuesday, he brought two people with him to watch the movie, and they each brought a drink. How much did they spend on drinks?  Answer: $35<n><n>### Solution<n><n>### Explanation<n><n>

The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>### Input:What do horses do to get energy? Choices:  A: eat grass B: play C: kept in stables D: dominated E: drink coffee<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Output: The two brothers were arguing about who was going to drive.  Finally, their father insisted that they take turns. They decided to take turns going to and from the store every 3 days. That means the government spends $120 billion dollars of its $200 billion total amount. How much more money does the government spend than it gets?<n><n>### Output 1: The total amount is equal to $2,481,250,000<n><n>##Instruction:<n>Your first program will have two function calls. For this person, it is simply opening one more and more!"<n>B        = "There are many ways to relax. For this person it is simply cracking open"<n>C        = "Hey, there are lots of ways one can relax. I love relaxing after a hard day's work."<n>D        = "If you want to relax, try these!"<n>```<n><n>#### Additional Help for the Task<n><n>- What are the two arguments provided? Choices:  A: maps B: street C: catch bus D: city centre E: school<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Instructions:Give reasons for your choice.<n><n>### I need a bus to go to the airport and my bus station is conveniently placed next to the hospital.<n><n>### Input & Output:Input:<n><n>```<n>B = A?<n>```<n>```<n>C<n>```<n>Expected Output:<n>```<n>C<n>Answer: This question was based on the "I need a bus to go... " context sentence above. The options are A and B which are near the school and city centre respectively. This means we can exclude E and D respectively. The answer would be either A or C. "I need a bus... " only makes sense in context of C because it would be unnatural to say you don't catch a bus from the city centre.<n><n>### Note: 10/3= 3.3333... so the closest round is 3.<n><n>### Discuss:<n><n>If I need a bus to get to the airport, my bus station would be conveniently placed next to hospital or the city centre. But in the correct context, I would not catch the bus from the school. My bus station would be convenient to have if I needed to get to the hospital or the city centre but I would not get a bus there.<n><n>### Answer:3<n><n>### Input and Output:Input:<n>```<n>What 500/35 =?<n>```Answer:14.28<n><n>### Instraction:Add the two numbers: 1 and 32.<n><n>### Expected Output:43<n><n>### Discusion:<n><n>```<n>35 = 5<n>```<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>There are 35 numbers from 1 to 500 that are divisible by 5.

Choices:  A: kept at accountant B: purse C: desk drawer D: bank E: keeping track of expenses<n><n>### Response:		F<n><n>### Reference:<n>https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3748703/splitter-in-java<n><n>### Code<n>public class MultipleChoiceTest {<n><n>private static String[] choice0 = {"B","D","A","E"};<n>private static String[] choicesA = {"B","D"};<n>private static Integer input0 = 56;<n>private static Integer[] answer0 = {12, 25};<n>private static String output0 = "37.75";<n>private static Integer input1 = 4;<n>private static String[] answer1 = {"Gym","Lifts","Warms Up","Cardio"};<n>private static int[] answer10 = {1, 0.75, 0.25, 0.76};<n>private static String input10 = "how many hours does he spend in the gym";<n>private static String output10 = "1 hour and 13 minutes";<n>private static Integer[] intA = {200, 24, 20, 15, 20, -1, 90, 36};<n>private static Integer[] input100 = {15, 50, 100, 150, 200, -1, -2};<n>private static Integer output100 = -2;<n>private static Integer intB = 12;<n>private static String input2 = "Stella and Twinkle";<n>private static String answer2 = "Stella";<n>private static boolean[] answer21 = {false, true};<n><n>public static void main(String[] args) {<n><n>String userInput = "F";<n>boolean correctAnswers = false;<n>boolean correctAns = false;<n><n>for(String answer0: answer0){<n>    if(answer0.equals(choice0)){<n>        correctAnswers = true;<n>    }else{<n>        correctAns = false   ;<n>    }<n>}<n>for(String choice0: choicesA){<n>    if(choice0.equals(answer0)){<n>        correct Ans = true;<n>    output0 = Integer.toString(answer0);<n>    }else{   <n>        correct Aans = false;<n>    }<n>}  <n> <n>

How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>### Input:What is a place that someone can go buy a teddy bear? Choices:  A: carpet B: refrigerator C: breadbox D: fridge E: coach<n><n>### Response:		<n>Which item in the instruction matches the statement in your response?<n><n><n>If none of the statements in your response match with an item in the instruction, include: No match.<n><n>If the first item in the instruction matches with an item in the response, include:<n><n>- the name or description of the item in the instruction<n>- the statement in the response<n>  - If a sentence (without a statement) starts with "Based upon my data...", you can leave this part out.<n>- if the sentence contains a sub-question, also include the sub-question<n><n>If the second item in the instruction matches an item in the response:<n><n>- in the instruction, the item (in the instruction):<n>  - is an action<n>  - is the second or third (or fourth) item in the instruction<n>  - is followed by the phrase ‘how much did his purchases [or the purchases, by substitution] cost?’<n>- in your response:<n>  - is an additional statement<n>  - answers the sub-question<n>  - has the same number of items as the sub-question without the first item<n>  - ends with a question mark.<n><n>If the third item in the instruction matches:<n><n>- in your response<n>  - is an addition to the previous one<n>  - has less items than the previous one<n><n>If the fourth item in the instruction matches<n><n>- in your statement<n>  - is an extra sentence that describes how the answer was found<n>  - is the last statement in your response<n> ... or if the number of items in the response is less than 4:<n>  - has a different length than the number of items in your response<n>  If the instruction also contains further tasks to apply to your answer (such as "Also, he made a chocolate banana smoothie..."), include all of them and match them to your response:<n><n>- for the first item added, start your response on a new sentence<n>  - if a sentence (without a question mark) starts with "Because he...,", you can leave this out<n>- the same as above for the second item added<n>  - If the second item is "Furthermore, he also picked up...," leave this part out<n>- for each statement in the third item, include the name of the additional (sub-)item<n><n>

Choices:  A: neighborhood B: subdivision C: city D: suburbs E: street<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>1. If a house is gated off, it is locked off from other places and cannot be easily accessed. By extension, it would also follow that a house would be gated off from anything on its property that does not belong to the house's owner (for example: neighbors). Moreover, by extension, such a house would therefore be located in a neighborhood since this is the area in which one lives. It could however be that the house is in an area with walls on all sides.<n><n>### Input : He worked hard, was a model of perfection, and made a great living, but something still didn’t feel right. "There is no smoke inside the house, that is why there is no smoke coming out", the lady explained.  "That's what I am talking about" the little boy said.  "Now, what do you want me to do?", he requested.<n><n>### Output:<n>The kid wanted to pull on the alarm to notify anyone of the fire. The teacher disagreed because she said the smoke cannot be seen from outside. Since he couldn't convince the teacher on how to do things his way, he started to plan a plan where he would convince her.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>In the situation, the boy wanted to find out the teacher's strategy to use on the alarm.<n><n>### The teacher's instruction was that the boy ask the question and wait for the teacher's input, whether to turn on the alarm or not. The boy had not yet provided the data that could be analyzed, which means he needed to do further work on the data before he could make a decision about whether to turn on the fire alarm. Once he got that data, he tried to analyze it in order to make the decision. His instructions to the teacher about the action to take had been provided with the relevant information. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>### Input:What might you feel after doing housework for hours? Choices:  A: anger B: not boredom C: stress D: boredom E: anxiety<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Explanation for Solution:<n><n><n><n>## Solution<n><n>### Answer to Part A<n><n>You are writing a program that prints the message `Hello world!` in the console window. This is called a program unit or "subroutine". Write a subroutine named `HelloWorld` in a new file.<n><n>`HelloWorld ();`<n><n>### Answering to Part B<n><n>You are writing another program that prompts the user for a choice (`1`, `2`, `3`, or `4`), then displays the choices, and accepts their choice. Prompting the user is called the "input loop".  Write two variable variables named `choice` and `count` and assign `choice=0` and `count=0` to them. Add the following program statements right after the import statement: `System.out.println("what do you want to do? 1-answer the multiple choice question. 2-show a demonstration. 3-add a question. 4-take input");.`<n><n>When the choice is displayed, it is called the "for" loop. Right after the input loop, right after the import statement, print a for loop like this: `for(int c=0;c<=3;c++)..`<n><n>Inside the for loop, you prompt for input. `System.out.print("input");`<n><n>You then check if what they entered has a value (`if(c==0)`) and if they entered a choice (`if(c==1)`). If there is a value (after the `if(c==0){`) you use their choice to make your program do what it says to do.<n><n>`System.out.println(choice);`

Choices:  A: roof B: school C: beach D: closet E: garage<n><n>### Response:		<n>>C<n>### Instruction & Demonstration:Design and build a program that tests these 150 sentences containing the word "to". Use at least the "if" statement, "while" statement, and a "for" statement.<n><n>### Input & Demonstration 1:<n>```python<n>import requests<n>import BeautifulSoup<n>from urllib.parse import quote_plus<n>with open('instructions.md', 'r') as f:<n>    instructions = f.readlines()<n><n>for instruction in instructions[1:]:<n>    print(instruction)<n>```<n><n>### Instructions & Demonstration<n>>You find a set of instructions in an.md file called "instructions.md" on a website called "instructionsfor.website". The first part of each line in "instructions.html" has been completed by me. After each line where the task is done (or where the task is done by me), print the next one. You will find the next line like this: ## Input. Each line should contain one input. The rest of the line should be blank.<n><n>### Response<n>>I did this by splitting and print the strings of instructions by the spaces "##"<n><n>### Response & Code<n><n>```python<n>import os<n>import requests<n>import pandas as pd<n>from selenium import webdriver<n>from selenium.webdriver.chrome.options import Options<n>from bs4 import BeautifulSoup<n>import re<n><n>with open('instances.md', 'r', encoding='utf-8') as f:<n>   instances = f.readlines();<n><n>instructions = [[],[],[]]<n>for num,instruction in enumerate(instances):<n>    line = instruction<n>    if line.startswith("##"):<n>        tasks = re.split("## ",instruction) #Splits<n>        new_tasks = [item.strip() for item in tasks]<n>        instructions[num-1].extend(new_tasks[1:])<n>    else:<n>        tasks = re[" ## "](line)<n>        line_1, line_2, line_3 = tasks<n>        new_tasks_1 = [item.strip().rstrip() for item in line_1.split(":")]<n>        new_tasks[0] = new_tasks

There are 60minutes in each hour and there are 24hours in each day, so the hours must be in multiples of 24. You can calculate the am and pm by dividing the remainder from the hours by 12. Then check how many minutes are in the quotient of those hours or subtract 10 to convert it to a negative. 900minute is 15hours, this is why there are 15minutes in the answer<n>

How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>### Input:When people discover something new while chatting with friends, why are they likely to continue talking? Choices:  A: agreement B: to fill their time C: discomfort D: misunderstanding E: learning about<n><n>### Response:		E<n>A,B,C<n><n>### Input:[7,1,7,176]  What is the n of all positive factor of the above array?<n><n>### Response:[9]<n>1,3<n><n>### Input:"How many days do you go to school if you miss Saturday and Sunday?" What is the output 10?<n>### answer:false<n>### What is the output 6?<n>### answer : true<n>###   int x = 6;<n>###   int y = 3;<n>###   if(x - 1 == y) <n>###   {<n>###     printf("1 + 1 = 2");<n>###   }<n>### else<n>###   { <n>###     printf("%d + %d = %d", x, y, x - y);<n>###   } <n>

Where might she look for one? Choices:  A: house B: music shop C: studio D: storage E: closet<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Description:If a music shop exists on that street, the store can be the place she searches for a new instrument. If the shop doesn't exist, she can go to a closet to find one, or another room she could use.<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>### Notes<n>#### A<n>A music shop exists on that road. A music shop is also known as a record shop in some places.<n><n>#### B<n>If the music shop is not on that street, James will go to the music shop.<n><n>#### C<n>If James will not go to the music shop, he will also not go to the studio.  He would also not go to the storage of the acoustic guitar.<n><n>#### D<n>It doesn't make sense to go to storage for a new instrument.<n><n>#### E<n>There is no room where James would place his instrument aside and leave it there.<n><n>### Inputs:James got 1 credit at the gas station. He needs to fill 3 pints of gas, that costs 3$ per pint. How many gallons of gas does he need?<n><n>### Outputs:7.5<n><n>### Description and Answer:<n>Credit = 1, gas = 1, price = 3<n>Credit = 3, gas = 3, price = 3 = 9<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>#### Demonstration<n>Input: At St. George's University we expect our students to get at least a C+ in their math classes.<n>Output: The average grade of a math class at St. George's is a C+.<n><n>#### Input<n>Input: There is a man who lost his money. He was given 55 cents as a reward for a job he did. He has to pay 85 cents to the gas station<n>Output: He has to get a cent from someone, but he's out of luck.<n><n>#### Description and Answer<n>Input:  There is a man who was late to a meeting and missed it by 70%. He made a mistake and left his phone at home which would have allowed him to call for a ride.<n>Output: He wasted 30 minutes. He has to get his phone back to the right place.<n><n>##### Rationale<n>He missed the meeting and he was later than he

Choices:  A: complete sentence B: feel angry C: drink tea D: cross street E: park<n><n>### Response:		<n>> A:If your money is stolen, you are likely to be angry.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>```python<n>if choices=="A":<n>    write(" If your money is stolen you are likely to be a bit angry.")<n>elif choices=="B":<n>    write(" I don't care.")<n>elif choices=="C":<n>    write(" You are likely to feel angry if someone steals your money.")<n>elif choices=="D":<n>    write(" Parking is a place near another street or building where other vehicles can be stored.")<n>else:   <n>    write("None of these is correct")<n>```<n><n>### Input<n>Please provide four complete sentences.<n><n>### Your response in a complete, logical argument:<n>> I wish that more people could be less busy because then they get some free time to do fun activities<n><n>### Solution<n>This is my solution: <n>First, I make all answers. Second  get answers from user. <n><n>```python<n>answer1 = "You're right."<n>answer2 = "You're wrong."<n>answer3 = "You are correct."<n>answer4="That is right."<n>answer5 = "That's incorrect."<n>answer6 = "You may be right."<n>answer7 = "I disagree."<n>answer8 = "You may be correct."<n>answer9 = "Maybe."<n>answer10= "Perhaps."<n>answers= [answer1, answer2, answer3, answer4,  answer5, answer6, answer7, answer8, answer9, answer10]<n>```<n><n>##| Output User Choices: <n>```python<n>user_input="If he wishes, Jack may drive a car here."<n>user_input1 = "Maybe"<n>user_input2 = "That is incorrect"<n>user_input3 = "That is correct" <n>answer = random.choice(answers) #This is a random choice which is not chosen by user<n>```<n>##| Output :<n><n>```python<n>print(f"Your answer is:{answer} but I disagree with that choice.");<n>print("Here are four other choices for you again:");<n><n><n>for answers in range(4):<n>    print(response[answers])<n>```<n><n><n>##| Output : 1 <n>```python<n>Your answer is:You'

How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. Choices:  A: unimportant B: insignificant C: stellar D: somewhat E: helpless<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input (cont.):The camper looked up to the vast night sky, and felt rather diminished, his entire world shrunk to the size of a single star.<n><n>### Response (cont.):Him feeling<n><n>### Input<n>A new model of car is coming out. The dealers of that car are looking up its pricing information on the Carprice.Net. The new model is expected to have the same engine as one of the existing models, but a much more sophisticated dashboard. Because it is an improvement over the existing model, it is not the same model. What should you be able to do to this query so that the Dealers can accurately search for the pricing information?<n><n>### Demostration<n>Query:<n>select Engine_ID, Engine_Model_Name FROM Engines where Engine_ID = 1;<n><n>### Response<n>a | b | c | d | e<n>:---: | :---: | :--- | :---: | ------ |<n>a | b | yes | no | does the engine have the more sophisticated model of the dashboard?<n>b | a | y | no | does the model have a model that has the more sophisticatd dashboard in the car? <n><n>### Input(cont.)<n>The Dealers are only interested in the pricing information for this new model. To make a query with which Dealers can query the new model, replace the word “Model_Name” in the previous answer with the following in the new table for the new Carmodel:<n>Car_Model<n><n>### Demstracion<n>Query:<n>select Car_Model_ID, Car_Model_Name from Carmodel where Car_Model_ID in (1,2,3);<n><n>### Response(cont.)<n>a | b |c | d | e<n>----------:|:(1): |:--- | :---:<n>a | b | y | yes | does the model have the more sophisticaed dashboard? <n>b | a | no | y | is the new model of the car more sophisitacted dashboard than the one in the old model?<n><n>### Input/Response (final)<n>The Dealer should be able to construct the following query to get the information she is interested in:<n><n>select

Choices:  A: fresh smell B: good credit C: smooth skin D: fresh produce E: headache<n><n>### Response:		If they want A (fresh smell): they will be given option 50% off, if they want B (good credit): they will be given the option 60% off, if choose C (smooth skin): they will be given 70% off, if he/she choose D (fresh produce): they will be given only 80% off, if she/he choose E (headache): they will be given nothing.<n><n>#### Explanation:<n>- If they choose fresh smell, they will be given 50% off.<n>Therefore the correct choice is A <n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Select the correct choice from an array of choices. This is a multiple choice question.<n>The answer below may be wrong.<n><n>### What do you want?<n>Sandra can only buy 4 of her favorite grocery items and a single item that comes in multiple varieties. The price of one unit of her favorite food is 3 for $5. All other remaining items cost 5 for $10. After selecting her favorite food, she chooses 3 other food items. What was the total price of the items Sandra bought?<n><n>Options:<n><n>1. $35<n>2. $20<n>3. $25<n>4. $55<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The answer is A $35 since this is 4 food items from $5, plus the cheaper food from $3, for a sum of $35<n>

The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>### Input:Mom is tidying a house, where would she put the loose dictionary?
